review.title: Artificial Persuasion in Pedagogical Games
review.abstract: A Persuasive Teachable Agent (PTA) is a special type of Teachable Agent which incorporates a persuasion theory in order to provide persuasive and more personalized feedback to the student. By employing the persuasion techniques, the PTA seeks to maintain the student in a high motivation and high ability state in which he or she has higher cognitive ability and his or her changes in attitudes are more persistent. However, the existing model of the PTA still has a few limitations. Firstly, the existing PTA model focuses on modelling the PTA's ability to persuade, while does not model its ability to be taught by the student and to practice the knowledge it has learnt. Secondly, the quantitative model for computational processes in the PTA has low reusability. Thirdly, there is still a gap between theoretical models and practical implementation of the PTA.

sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text: A Persuasive Teachable Agent (PTA) is a special type of Teachable Agent that includes a belief theory to provide the student with compelling and more personalized feedback. By using persuasion methods, the PTA tries to keep the student in a high state of motivation and achievement, in which he or she has higher cognitive abilities and his or her attitudes are more persistent. Second, the existing PTA model still has some limitations. First, the existing PTA model focuses on the ability to convince while not modelling his or her ability to be taught by the student and the knowledge he or she has learned to practice. Second, the quantitative model of computational processes in the PTA has low reusability. Third, there is still a gap between theoretical models and the practical implementation of the PTA system.

sections.heading: Agent
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 1.1 Motivation
sections.text: This year, the time has come for an agreement to be reached, and it will only take a few days.

sections.heading: 1.2 Research Objectives
sections.text: By incorporating the idea of persuasion, the PTA can achieve greater spontaneity, generate more personalized feedback, and bring about long-term changes in attitudes toward learning. However, the existing PTA model has several limitations: (1) The Persuasion Reasoning of PTA is not integrated with Teachability and Practicability Reasoning. (2) The quantitative model in Persuasion Reasoning of PTA is difficult to reuse and persuasive. The existing model focuses on the representation of the ability of the PTA to convince, but does not describe the ability to be taught and practiced. (2) The quantitative model in Persuasion Reasoning of PTA is difficult to reuse. Existing PTA models use a blurred tool, Fuzzy Cognitive Map (FCM), tomodel the computational processes in Persuasion Reasoning.

sections.heading: 1.3 Contributions
sections.text: The key contributions of this project include: A complete and integrated PTA agent model. The agent model represents a PTA in its totality. o Persuasion Reasoning. The compelling argumentation model in the existing PTA model is simplified and integrated with Teachability Reasoning and Practicability Reasoning. o Teachability Reasoning. An argumentation model for Teachability is added. o Practicability Reasoning: A practicable argumentation model is added to demonstrate the practicability of the PTA. o An improved quantitative model for the Persuasion Reasoning of the PTA. The quantitative model can be reused in different contexts. For example, it can be reused for PTA in different areas of knowledge and with different implementations. New system architecture for the PTA. The system architecture mainly shows a PTA implementation, especially with regard to control structures.

sections.heading: 1.4 Report Organization
sections.text: Chapters in this report are structured as follows: Chapter 2 describes research, studies and experiments in the field of Teachable Agent and Persuasive Teachable Agent. Since the implemented PTA is embedded in a game in a 3D environment, related work on educational games and virtual environments is also presented. Chapter 3 redefines PTA and introduces the enhanced drug model. Chapter 4 presents the proposed system architecture. Chapter 5 shows the practice of implementing a PTA according to the proposed drug model and system architecture. Chapter 6 presents the case studies of the implemented PTA. It also describes the approach to evaluating the PTA and summarizes the evaluation results.Chapter 7 concludes this project and discusses possible areas for future work.Chapter 2 Literature Review

sections.heading: 2.1 Teachable Agents
sections.text: The idea of the teacher (TA) is inspired by pedagogy, which involves learning by teaching others.

sections.heading: Teachable
sections.text: Even with the improved TA models, such as Affective Teachable Agent and DynaLearn, there are still two problems with learning with TAs [20]: (1) Students may not have mastered the subject when teaching the TA. This can cause the student to make mistakes during class. In this situation, it is difficult to give constructive feedback by focusing solely on the TA's learning performance. It is critical to understand the student's skills, i.e. how much he or she knows at the time he or she is teaching, in order to provide appropriate feedback. (2) Students are not fully involved in the TA's teaching. To take full advantage of learning-by-teaching, the student must actively participate in teaching. However, it is difficult to keep the student motivated all the time, especially if the TA is passive in interactions and unable to provide personalized answers. Therefore, it is important to monitor the student's motivation level and to have appropriate feedback for the student to have the TA's existing ability to generate the responses most of the problems.

sections.heading: 2.2 Persuasive Teachable Agents
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: 2.3 Educational Games and Virtual Environments
sections.text: As digital natives, most students today have played games, and some have even made the game an integral part of their lives. Games, especially video games, are highly engaging and can deliver content because of their appealing audio and video effects. Studies of educational video games suggest that they can help students master content [8] and acquire practical skills [9]. Most video games are used in 2D or 3D environments. River City is a multi-user virtual environment built by Chris Dede's group at Harvard University to facilitate science learning [17]. After two weeks, the group of students who played in River City improved their content knowledge and knowledge to a greater extent than the control group that followed the normal paper-based curriculum. Teaching agents can also be embedded in educational video games.

sections.heading: Agent
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.1 Redefining PTA
sections.text: It is an agent that can be defined by a tuple of PTA = (E, Et, K, Rs, R, A). It is the set of environmental states that can be perceived by the agent in each cycle; it is the set of perceptions / events that the agent perceives in his environment; it is the set of knowledge that is claimed by the agent; it is the set of selection mechanisms that the agent adopts to choose an argumentation in each cycle; it is the set of reasoning that the agent is able to perform; R can be further defined by the tuple R = (P, Pr, Pr). It is the set of actions that the agent is able to apply to the environment. Definition 2: R can be defined by the tuple R. (P, Tr, Pr), whereP stands for persuasion.

sections.heading: 3.2 Modelling the Main Routine of PTA
sections.text: Section 3.2.1 will first present the methodology used to model PTA. Section 3.2.2 will then focus on modeling the main PTA routine using this methodology.

sections.heading: 3.2.1 Goal Net Methodology
sections.text: The Goal-Net methodology is well suited for modeling goal-oriented actors. As goal-orientation is one of the most important features of the PTA, Goal Net would be an appropriate methodology for modeling the PTA. The Goal-Net methodology was first proposed in 2005 by Dr. Shen [16] to model goal-oriented actors. In Goal Net, an actor pursues his goal by completing a sequence of sub-goals. A Goal-Net can be composed of four basic units: states, transitions, arcs, and diversions. States are used to represent the goals of an actor. A state can be atomic or composite. A composite state can be further broken down into several atomic states. These atomic states represent the sub-goals that need to be fulfilled in order to fulfill the goal designated by the composite state. States are represented by a round node in Goal networks transitions, which are the transitions of a state to an agent.

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Modelling PTA Main Routine with Goal Net
sections.text: The main routine is the top goal-net model of the PTA (Figure 3.4), as it represents the agent's actual goal. The design of the main routing reflects the definition of the PTA in Section 3.1. There are similarities between the states and transitions of the main routine and the components of the PTA model, as shown in Table 3.1.

sections.heading: States/Transitions in Main Routine Component in PTA Definition
sections.text: In the main routine, correspondences can also be found for the three cycles of the PTA defined in definition 3. From the start node to the end node, the execution of the "Learn Knowledge" branch would complete a cycle of teaching; the execution of the "Learn Knowledge" branch to the end node would complete a cycle of practice; the execution of the "Convince Knowledge" branch to the end node would complete a cycle of persuasion; the main routine is executed repeatedly so that the agent is constantly pursuing its goal; in each cycle, the agent repeatedly checks for events until one or more events are detected; depending on the event perceived, the agent selects a suitable reasoning mechanism and executes the corresponding sub-target network of the chosen reasoning; after completion of the current cycle, the agent loads the start node of the main routine and begins the next cycle; the three sub-target networks are described in detail in the following sections.

sections.heading: 3.3 Persuasion Reasoning of PTA
sections.text: Section 3.3.1 will explain the belief theory that forms the basis for Persuasion Reasoning. Section 3.3.2 will then explain the quantitative model used for the calculation processes in Persuasion Reasoning. Finally, Section 3.3.3 will propose the goal-net model of Persuasion Reasoning.

sections.heading: 3.3.1 Persuasion Theory of PTA – ELM
sections.text: The belief theory that forms the basis for persuasion work is the Elaboration Likelihood Model (ELM). The Elaboration Likelihood Model (ELM) of persuasion is a dualistic model developed by Petty and Cacioppo in 1986. ELM proposed a basic framework for persuasion communication and the resulting attitude. Elaboration in the ELM refers to the process in which the recipient of the persuasive message engages in cognitive thinking in connection with the persuasive topic. Various factors that can influence the likelihood of elaboration can be classified into large categories: motivation of the message recipient and his or her ability to elaborate. According to the ELM, there are two ways of persuasive work, the central route and the peripheral route as shown in the figure.

sections.heading: 3.3.2 Quantitative Model for Assessing Motivation and Ability – FCM
sections.text: As mentioned above, the PTA must determine the student's motivation and ability to generate an appropriate response. FCM can be used to derive the values of motivation and ability from the values of their respective constituent factors. Fuzzy Cognitive Map (FCM) is a fuzzy tool that can be used to represent causal relationships in dynamic systems. FCM is a graphical representation that simultaneously represents a mathematical model of the dynamic system. FCM consists of causal concepts and causal relationships. A causal concept can be used to model an event, a goal or an action. It is represented by a rounded node in FCM and has a real numerical value in interval.

sections.heading: 3.3.3 Modelling Persuasion Reasoning with Goal Net
sections.text: The sub-target network of the sub-target network (Figure 3.8) describes how the PTA pursues its sub-target "persuasion," and persuasion is one of the important characteristics that characterize a PTA. In pursuit of its sub-target "persuasion," a PTA would act to keep the student on the central path of persuasion, i.e. to keep him in high motivation and high performance. First, when this sub-target network is executed, the agent evaluates the values of motivation and ability according to the fuzzy cognitive map model proposed in Section 3.3.2. Second, the agent determines whether the resulting motivation and performance values are high or low by comparing them with the pre-defined baseline values. If both motivation and performance values are high, no special measures are required.

sections.heading: 3.4 Teachability Reasoning of PTA
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.4.1 Integration with Practicability and Persuasion
sections.text: The point of integration between the Teachability Reasoning and the Practicability Reasoning is the knowledge base. In a teaching cycle, the PTA learns from the student and stores the knowledge learned in the knowledge base. In the subsequent Practicability Reasoning cycle, the Practicability Reasoning reads the stored knowledge. Teachability Reasoning must also be integrated into the Persuasion Reasoning. During the teaching cycle, all signs that indicate that the student is not motivated or capable are detected, so that the Persuasion Reasoning can process it later in a persuasion cycle.

sections.heading: 3.4.2 Modelling Teachability Reasoning with Goal Net
sections.text: The Sub-Target Network of Teachability Reasoning (Figure 3.9) describes how the PTA pursues its sub-target of "learning knowledge." In executing this sub-target network, the agent first requires the student to teach it. Second, he waits for the student's response and reviews it. If the student agrees to teach the PTA, the PTA will learn from the student and store the knowledge acquired in the knowledge base. However, if the student is not motivated to teach the PTA or does not have the ability, he or she would refuse the PTA's teaching request. In this case, the PTA generates a rejection event. This event is recognized by the PTA in the next cycle. Since the refusal indicates that the student has either low motivation or low ability, the agent will decide to undergo a persuasion logic during the execution of a rejection event.

sections.heading: 3.5 Practicability Reasoning of PTA
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 3.5.1 Integration with Teachability and Persuasion
sections.text: In a case where the student tutor makes mistakes during the course, the mistakes should be recorded and signalled during the practical suitability course, so that the Teachability Reasoning can highlight the errors during the next course cycle. Praxability Reasoning must also be integrated into the Persuasion Reasoning. During the practical cycle, events are recorded and signalled that could lead the student to a low motivation or achievement level, so that the Persuasion Reasoning can process it later in a persuasion cycle.

sections.heading: 3.4.2 Modelling Practicability Reasoning with Goal Net
sections.text: The sub-target network of the Practicability Reasoning (Figure 3.10) describes how the PTA pursues its sub-target: "To Practice Knowledge Learned." When executing this sub-target network, the agent first queries the knowledge base to retrieve the knowledge acquired by the student. Second, he derives a solution from the knowledge through reasoning. If the resulting solution is correct, he executes the solution. However, if the resulting solution is wrong, the agent creates a wrong solution event, which is detected by the agent in the next cycle. Since the student can be demotivated after this fail trail, the PTA chooses to perform the Persuasion Reasoning if a wrong solution event is detected. After executing this sub-target network, the agent executes the next node after the composite state "To Practice Knowledge Learned" on the main route.

sections.heading: 4.1 Overall System Architecture Design
sections.text: Chapter 3 proposes an improved agent model for the PTA. However, since the agent model has a high degree of abstraction, there is still a gap between this theoretical model and the implementation of the PTA. In order to provide further guidelines for implementation, a new system architecture for the PTA is proposed in this chapter. The proposed system architecture (as shown in Figure 4.1) focuses on the design of the control structure of the agent. The system architecture retains a certain degree of abstraction and is reusable as: (1) It is independent of the learning topics, deployment environment and execution form of the PTA; (2) It guides, but does not restrict, the way of implementing a PTA. At the highest level, the Goal Net interpreter directs the goal-oriented behaviors of a PTA according to its Goal Net models. It determines the next state of the PTA and the tasks to be performed in order to move to the next state.

sections.heading: Component Functionality/ Role
sections.text: Database access connects to the database and performs queries In the following sections, each component of the system architecture is explained in more detail: (1) its main functionality; (2) its interactions with other components; (3) ways to implement this component.

sections.heading: 4.2 Goal Net Interpreter
sections.text: The Goal Net Interpreter guides the goal-oriented behavior of a PTA according to the Goal Net Models introduced in Chapter 3. As shown in Figure 4.2, the proposed Goal Net models of the PTA can be created by drawing using a graphical Goal Net Designer and fed into the Goal Net Database. It determines the next state of the PTA by drawing through the nodes of the Goal Net. The Goal Net Interpreter loads the Goal Net models from the database during the term and interprets them dynamically. It determines the next state of the PTA by traversing the goals of the Goal Net.

sections.heading: 4.3 PTA Control
sections.text: While the Goal Net Interpreter directs the agent's goal-oriented behavior, the PTA Control coordinates it. The Goal Net Interpreter instructs the PTA Control to perform certain tasks by calling corresponding task functions in the PTA Control. As the task functions are executed, the PTA Control splits the tasks into subtasks and sends them to other components by calling corresponding modules in these components. In this way, all components work toward the goal of the PTA Collective.In order to realize all three cycles of a PTA defined in Definition 3, the PTA Control must implement the task functions listed in Table 4.2. Each of these task functions is associated with a transition in the Goal Net models of the PTA. A task function has the same name as the transition to which it is assigned. Table 4.2 Task functions to be implemented in the PTA Control.

sections.heading: Goal Net Model Functions to be Implemented
sections.text: Main Routine RecognitionEventInterpretationEventSelectReasoning FinishTo Learn KnowledgeRequireTeaching CheckResponse InitializeTeaching AcquireKnowledgeSaveKnowledge GenerateRejectionEvent Finish

sections.heading: To Practice Knowledge
sections.text: LearntQueryKB Reasoning CarryOutSolGenerateWrongSolEvent FinishTo ConsuadeFCMCalculation CheckMotAbi SelectCueExecuteCue Finish

sections.heading: 4.4 Other Components Supporting PTA Control
sections.text: The PTA control coordinates the goal-oriented behaviors of the PTA and implements the most important functionalities of the PTA. Event control, FCM calculation and UI control are three components that support the PTA control. The three components deal with the perceptions, arguments and actions of the agent. Event control allows the agent to perceive his environment. FCM calculation allows the agent to think about the motivation and performance level of the student. UI control allows the agent to act on his environment.

sections.heading: 4.4.1 Event Control
sections.text: The event control component corresponds to the event tracker Et (see definition in Section 3.1) of the PTA. Event control controls the lifetime of an event. It is concerned with the creation, logging, processing and elimination of events. PTA control uses the functions in the event control to process events. It is more recommendable to implement event control through the event control mechanism with a check duration of a few seconds. During the check period, the newly generated events are logged in the event log of the event control. When checking, event control prioritizes the events and decides on the processing sequence of the events. It may also decide to process a number of interactive events in a batch.Table 4.3 suggests some types of events that can be tracked in a 2D or 3D PTA environment, together with appropriate examples.

sections.heading: Knowledge
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: Learning
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: Event Category Event Example

sections.heading: 4.4.2 FCM Calculation
sections.text: The FCM calculation component performs the calculation processes associated with FCM in the Persuasion Reasoning of the PTA. When the PTA is initialized, the FCM model is loaded from the database and stored in the FCM calculation component. In the Persuasion Reasoning cycle, the PTA controller calls the functions in the FCM calculation to calculate the motivation and performance of the students. There are two ways to implement the FCM calculation component free of charge. An interface can be created for these tools so that they can be used by the PTA control structure. The interface must handle the conversion and transmission of inputs to these tools and the restoration and reformatting of the results of these tools.This alternative would greatly reduce the effort required to create the FCM control structure.

sections.heading: Tool Name Descriptions Disadvantages
sections.text: FCMappers Based on Excel Visual representations for FCM on the Web Not easy to integrate Can not adjust FCM parameters or threshold functions

sections.heading: Mental
sections.text: Modeling Downloaded or Web-based GUIs to Draw FCM's Interface to Display FCMmatrix Not Easy to Integrate Can't Adjust FCM Limited's Parameters or Threshold Functions Causal Relationship Values (Can Be Selected from Few Values) JFCM Downloaded Java Program Creating FCM from scratch by Writing Java Code or Reading from XML Open Source Not Adapted for PTAFCM, Therefore, Does Not Reflect the Structure of PTA FCMAlternative 2: Creating a New FCM Tool From scratch. Building a New one requires More Effort. However, this alternative offers more Space for Customization and greatly reduces the Difficulty of Integration with Other Components. An Implementation of the Proposed PTA FCM Model is described in Section 5.2.4.

sections.heading: 4.4.3 UI Control
sections.text: The UI Control component corresponds to the Actuator A (see definition in Section 3.1) of the PTA. It contains modules that allow the agent to interact with various aspects of his environment, including the visual representation of himself in the environment. Thus, for example, the PTA can be integrated into his environment as a 2D figure or as a 3D avatar. The UI Control provides modules that can control the figure or avatar of the PTA. The UI Control can also control the graphical interfaces or visual effects in the PTA environment. See Section 5.4.3 for more examples.

sections.heading: 4.5 Database Access
sections.text: The database access component provides interfaces to the other components in order to access the database. Depending on the implementation of the PTA, multiple databases may need to be accessed. For example, the Goal Net Interpreter needs to access the state and transition information in the Goal Net database, while the FCM calculation component needs to load the FCM model from the FCM database. The database access component should be able to support and coordinate access to multiple databases. It should provide modules to connect to different database management systems in which the databases are administered. If two different databases are managed by the same database management system, the database access component needs to coordinate access to these two databases, as the best practice is to keep only one open connection at a time.

sections.heading: 5.1 Game Environment
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.1.1 Unity for 3D Game Development
sections.text: Unity is a development platform for creating 2D / 3D games and interactive experiences. Unity includes a game engine and an integrated development environment. VS Saga is a 3D video game developed for this project on the Unity development platform. In VS Saga, an instance of the PTA is embedded to demonstrate the practice of instantiating a PTA from the proposed agent model and system architecture.

sections.heading: 5.1.2 Main Scenes and Story Lines
sections.text: This year, it is more than ever before until it is able to retaliate.

sections.heading: 5.2 Goal Net Interpreter
sections.text: The implemented Goal Net Interpreter accesses the Goal Net database directly via the interface provided by the database access component. The Goal Net Interpreter goes from an input state to an output state by triggering the transition that connects it. However, when it encounters a decision node for which an input state has several possible output states, it must decide which output state to switch to. To solve this problem, a decision table is implemented in the PTA Control component (as shown in Figure 5.5) that allows the decision to be made at each decision node. PTA Control updates this decision table according to the reasoning results and current perceptions. The Goal Net Interpreter refers to the decision table for deciding the output state when a decision node is found.

sections.heading: 5.3 PTA Control
sections.text: The PTA control has implemented the task functions in Table 4.2. This section contains summaries of how these functions are implemented in the context of the VS-Saga.Main routine. During the execution of the main PTA routine, the PTA control calls the event control every 5 seconds to search for events until one or more events are detected. Then, it prioritizes the events and decides which ones to process in the current cycle. It determines which of the argumentation cycles the event should go through and updates the decision table. Convinction work is done. While executing the sub-goal network, "the PTA control calls the FCM calculation component to calculate the value of motivation and ability based on current perceptions (events). Then, it compares the resulting values with the basic values to determine whether the student is in a low motion or low qualification state.

sections.heading: 5.4 Other Controllers Supporting PTA Control
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.4.1 Event Control
sections.text: In VS Saga, the event control component has mainly tracked and dealt with three types of events in Table 4.3: dialog events, time events and lesson feedback events. Dialogue events. A dialog event is an event that is generated when a particular sentence is spoken in a dialog system. A dialog event can be configured within the dialog system of the unit using a special script called SequencerCommand.The learner's dialogues with the game characters can be configured in the dialog system. Figure 5.9 shows the dialog entry of a sentence in the dialog between the student and the water molecule in unity. This sentence "B. I'm afraid I can't teach you," is spoken by the student to the water molecule to reject the teaching request.The blue rectangle in Figure 5.10 highlights the SequencerCommand GenerateEvent that is called when this sentence is spoken. Figure 5.10 shows the command sequence sequence of the GenerateEvent.

sections.heading: 5.4.2 FCM Calculation
sections.text: Instead of using existing FCM tools, an FCM calculation component is developed so that it can be easily integrated with other control components developed in the Unit. FCM calculation component is implemented in accordance with the FCM model proposed in Section 3.3.2. The complete PTA FCM class can be found in Appendix 4.A Class Diagram of the FCM calculation component in Figure 5.11. From the bottom of the chart, the AdjacencyList class will store the representation of the PTA FCM. The PTA FCM can be represented by an economical matrix. Compared to a 2D matrix, the adjacency list of suitable data structures is used to achieve higher room efficiency.

sections.heading: 5.4.3 UI Control
sections.text: This section contains some examples to show how the UI control manages the various UIs.Persuasion Reasoning.The TA panel (Figure 5.13) is the most important interface element for the Persuasion Reasoning.It is used to display the persuasion signals.After a persuasion signal has been selected, the PTA control component calls the UI control to retrieve and display the information of the selected signal.The information to be retrieved from the database includes the texts to be displayed and the facial expression of the water molecule. Teachability Reasoning.The concept map (Figure 5.14) is the most important interface at which the teaching process is carried out. To teach the PTA (the water molecule), the student completes the concept map by dragging and dropping the buttons on the empty spaces on the right.

sections.heading: 5.5 Database Access
sections.text: In VS Saga, the data access component must provide interfaces for two database management systems, MySQL and SQLite. The Goal Net database and the FCM database are managed by MySQL, while the Convinction and Inventory database by SQLite. Inventory information and persuasion sources are stored in the same database that is managed by SQLite. Therefore, there are no access problems. However, the Goal Net database and the FCM database are two separate databases, both managed by MySQL. Since the best course of action is to keep only one connection open at a time, access to these two databases must be coordinated. Database Access loads the FCM model during initialization from the FCM database and closes the connection to the FCM database. It then opens the connection to the Goal Net database and executes queries while the Goal Net interpreter studies the PTA target network and PTA chapter 6.

sections.heading: 6.1 Case Studies of PTA
sections.text: This section presents some case studies of the implemented PTA. They are intended to show that the PTA implemented in VS Saga has realized all the essential features of a PTA. These case studies will be used in future submissions to the IJCAI-15 video competition.

sections.heading: 6.1.1 Persuasion Case Studies
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

See the sad water molecule and the withered treeFigure 6.4 (a) Arrival at the banana tree4.2 Make mistakes while drawing the concept map = > Click on the "Teach!" button, go to Figure 4.3Figure 6.4 (b) Make mistakes during the lesson 4.3 No solution can be generated according to the practical reasoning.

sections.heading: Case Study 5: Teach Success after Previous Failure
sections.text: 5.1 Teach the water molecule again after it has failed for the first time. Mistakes made during the previous teaching process will be highlighted in red.5.1.1 If you fail to correct all mistakes = > Click "Teach!," go to 5.2Figure 6.5 (a) Teach the water molecule again.

sections.heading: 6.2 Qualitative Assessment of PTA
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 6.2.1 Assessment Approach – Focus Group Study
sections.text: For the qualitative assessment of the PTA, a focus group study will be carried out to gather feedback, comments and views on the PTA. As the PTA is located in the interdisciplinary research area of education, intelligent agents and psychology, the focus group should include participants from different areas to receive feedback and comments on various aspects of the PTA. The design of the focus group study is summarised in Table 6.1.5.2. After the practical reference, a correct solution will be derived. The practice reference module Reasoning calls on the UI control module of the tree to depict the tree's emulation, the tree is revitalised and the water molecule becomes happy.Figure 6.5 (b) Revitalised tree and happy water molecule 5.3 The water molecule provides positive feedback on the teaching.

sections.heading: Design of the Focus Group Study
sections.text: Number of Participants 6Education of Participants2 Secondary Teachers2 Agent Researcher 2 Game Developers Main Question A. Regarding the effectiveness of the PTA as a learning companion: (1) Do you believe that the PTA is convincing enough to influence the student's minds and decisions during the learning process and why? (2) How do you think the PTA can help the student understand the learning topics better and why? (3) How do you believe that the PTA is able to improve the student's learning outcomes and why? (4) How do you think the PTA can influence the student's attitude to learning? (5) Any areas for improvement? B. Regarding the PTA agent model: (1) Do you believe that the proposed agent model would increase the student's spontaneity and why? (2) Do you believe that the proposed agent model would help the PTA to generate personalized feedback and why? (3) Is the modeling of the agent model considered complete and flexible?

sections.heading: 6.2.2 Result Analysis of the Focus Group Study
sections.text: Since the number of participants in the focal group study is small, no statistical signature can be drawn from the study. However, it is valuable to summarize all qualitative assessments in order to identify the benefits and areas for improvement of the PTA. Processes would be summarized in the following table. The teaching process can help strengthen students "learning, not only for diffusion and osmosis. In assessing the student's ability, his or her ability to improve knowledge, the PTA should be able to.

sections.heading: 6.2.3 Limitations and Areas for Improvements
sections.text: The focus group study also identified some limitations and areas for improvement. The one that was addressed by most of the focus group participants is the lack of flexibility of the current PTA. The instance implemented in VS Saga is specific to topics in the scientific field. Greater flexibility needs to be included so that the PTA and the educational game can be adapted to different learning topics. To do this, there is a need to propose a convenient way to modify the agent's models and change the content of the knowledge base. One way to include this kind of flexibility is to design an authoring tool for the PTA so that the design and implementation process of the PTA can be linked more smoothly. This is an area that future research in the PTA can address. Another important area for Improventis is the student's learning competence and knowledge when assessing his or her performance level.

sections.heading: 7.1 Conclusions
sections.text: A Persuasive Teachable Agent (PTA) is a special type of Teachable Agent (TA) that has the ability to be taught, practice learned knowledge and convince the student to teach it. By incorporating the Elaboration Likelihood Model (ELM), the PTA is able to provide more up-to-date and personalized feedback based on the student's ability and motivation, which previous TAs were unable to do. However, the existing PTA model still has some limitations. Firstly, the existing agent model has only proposed positive feedback for Persuasion Reasoning, while there are no Goal Net models for Teachability Reasoning and Practicability Reasoning. Secondly, the FCM model for Persuasion Reasoning is difficult to reuse as it is highly context dependent. Thirdly, there is a gap between the theoretical models and the practical implementation of the PTA.

sections.heading: 7.2 Future Work
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 7.2.1 Quantitative Assessment of PTA
sections.text: During the focus group study, no statistically significant analysis can be drawn from the results because the number of participants is too small. No conclusions can be drawn as to how the PTA will affect the student's learning outcomes. Therefore, a quantitative evaluation of the PTA must be performed in order to statistically analyze the effectiveness of the PTA. VS Saga can be used for evaluation purposes on various platforms, such as desktops and tablets. Assessment can be performed with a pre-test, a post-test and a series of questionnaires. The pre-test and post-test can contain questions to assess the student's understanding of the content knowledge. By comparing the results of the two tests, the student's knowledge gain can be evaluated by teaching the PTA and his or her learning outcomes. The questionnaire can be used to supplement the tests and to survey the student's attitudes and feelings towards the PTA.

sections.heading: 7.2.2 PTA Authoring Tool
sections.text: As discussed in Section 6.2.3, the results of the focus group study have indicated some directions for future research. Therefore, before the PTA can be widely used, it must build up the flexibility to accommodate different learning topics. On different learning topics, the learning goal and related expertise would be different. Therefore, there is a need to suggest a convenient way to modify the agent's models and change the content of the knowledge base. [11] One way to integrate this kind of flexibility is to design an authoring tool for the PTA. Referring to the design of the authoring tool that Ailiya has proposed for the Affective Teachable Agent [11], a similar design for the author's tool for the PTA (Figure 7.1) can be proposed. A dedicated component for creating and editing learning goals, content knowledge, and game tasks can be created. If changes are made by the Game Authoring Component, the learning goals in the knowledge base of the teaching base should be updated and the learning objectives of the developer accordingly.

sections.heading: 7.2.3 Application of Educational Data Mining
sections.text: A major advantage of educational games is the provision of a digital environment in which a large amount of student behavioral data can be collected, which can be tracked and analyzed to give the student useful feedback on their learning progress. Table 4.3 lists 7 types of event data that can be tracked in the games. However, in VS Saga, the assessment of motivation and performance levels is largely based on immediate event data and only 3 of these 7 types of events are tracked. In future studies, efforts may be directed toward increasing the type of events. By analyzing other event sources, the PTA will be able to more accurately assess the student's motivation and performance level. In addition, future research could examine the use of educational data mining to analyze the relationship between different types of student behavioral data and the degree of motivation and ability.

sections.heading: Paper Submitted
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: Title
sections.text: Virtual world based on pedagogical data mining

sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text: The virtual environment is not only an efficient and engaging learning tool, but also has the potential to be integrated with Educational Data Mining (EDM) to meet the emerging needs of educational evaluation. Nowadays, traditional academic evaluation approaches cannot fully reflect students "learning skills, which are critical to their prosperity in a rapidly changing world. We also propose an evaluation system that integrates EDM seamlessly with the functionality and affordability of a virtual environment to assess students" learning literacy by analyzing their behavioral data and patterns. We also propose a set of metrics that can be used to evaluate students "learning competence and how these metrics can be evaluated computationally by quantifying and capturing students" behavioral data in a virtual environment. The field study conducted at Xinmin Secondary School in Singapore has shown that the proposed evaluation system is promising in determining useful behavioral measures for assessing learning competence.

sections.heading: Keywords
sections.text: Educational Data Mining; Virtual Environment; Competence Assessment; SelfDirected LearningAnnex 2 The Complete Target Network Model on the Target Network DesignerAnnex 3 Events Tracked in VS Saga
